entry.title: Command Lines and Shortcuts
entry.content:
I don't think there's a day where I haven't used a command line to do something a little extra or get behind the UI to complete tasks that developers didn't make straightforward for users. Sometimes, you don't want to give full control to a general user, but it would be nice to have a power user overlay in addition to the standard actions available to users. Here are some commands I use frequently throughout my days on the computer.

PowerShell

  1. winget upgrade - Lists all software Windows can update via powershell
  2. winget upgrade --all - This will update every listed item in one fell swoop. No need for those pesky PC manager softwares out there.

Windows

  1. Windows + V - With clipboard history enabled this brings up your history and you are able to pick and choose what to paste.
    • To activate. Press Windows + i. Search for Clipboard Setting. Turn on clipboard history. Thank me with a coffee
  2. Windows + Shift + S - Snip & Sketch tool. Screenshots are a must for what I do in my day to day.
  3. Windows + Arrow Keys - Quickly change where your application is positioned on the screen. Using the arrow keys while holding the Windows key will move the Application Window around.
  4. Windows + Shift + Arrow Key - BONUS - By holding the Window key, Shift and pressing an arrow key you will move the application window to another monitor if you have multiple setup.
  5. del /s /q /f /a ._* - To further help clean up the nuisance .DS_Store files from a Mac. Navigate to the directory and let this command fly!

Mac OS

  1. ⌘(cmd) + I - I always need to know the property of a file and this is my go to.
  2. find . -name ".DS_Store" -delete - Finds the annoying .DS_Store files and deletes them. If you transfer files you know what I am talking about!
  3. find . -name ".DS_Store" -type f -delete - Exclude directories and filter only for files.

RegEx

Sitemap pull URLs <loc>(https?://[^<]+)</loc>

Visual Studio Code follow up the Sitemap URL pull with CTRL + SHIFT + L for select highlights

entry.title: Helpful Tools
entry.content:
Accessibility

Colorable - Quick tool to check contrast by Brent Jackson.

Browser

Firefox - The one the only Mozilla Firefox. My browser of choice. I’ve been a fan for decades!

Design

Affinity - My new workflow revolves around the Affinity StudioLink functionality of Photo, Designer and Publisher by Serif.
Coolors [Affiliated Link] - Awesome colour palette generator and all around colour tool.
Penpot - An alternative to Figma, Sketch and XD.
Open Foundry - a free platform for curated open-source typefaces.

Email

MJML - Framework for building responsive emails.
Can I Email - Email Client support tables for HTML/CSS features.

Ideation

Coggle [Affiliated Link] - I’ve been using Coggle for years now to get my ideas out on a mind map.

Network

Pi-hole - A network-wide ad and tracking blocker that operates at the DNS level, efficiently blocking ads and improving internet browsing experience for all devices on the network.
Firebog - Blocklist Collection for the Pi-Hole.

Stock Assets

Dimensions - Site dedicated to dimensioned drawings with standard measurements and sizes of everyday objects and spaces from around the world.
Blue Vertigo - An amazing list of digital assets from stock photos to pattern mixes.
Unsplash - A source of freely usable images by creators. You will have seen several on my site.

Web Development

SVGOMG - Jake Archibald’s robust SVG tool. I’ve used this a lot throughout most of my projects. Big Thanks to Jake!
Can I Use - Browser support tables for modern web technologies.
Fluid Type Scale Calculator - Using CSS Clamp
Mozilla Developer Network - Web documents for CSS, HTML, JavaScript and more.
RegExr - a gskinner tool that is super useful for those times you are trying to crack a RegEx issue.

Windows Software

PowerToys - Ever want to make your Windows installed the way you want it? I’ve used several of the PowerToys to change how my PC works. Color Picker, FancyZones, File Locksmith, Image Resizer, Keyboard Manager, PowerRename, and Screen Ruler.
Sysinternals - A good host of applications really.
AutoRuns - Excellent software to see what’s running on your computer.
Process Explorer - A bit better then Task Manager…
MalwareBytes - Team this up with your Windows Defender application and you should be good to go.

entry.title: Contemplation
entry.content:
Taken from a Facebook memory I had on July 22, 2010

“Forked lightning rolling my way. Carved paths through an endless sky. Which path to take but for only a split second one must think…”

entry.title: Prusaslicer Settings
entry.content:
External Perimeters

This setting reverses the order of the perimeters set for a model. By default, its the internal perimeters before the external. However checking this box allows the print to be reversed. External before internal improving the quality and accuracy of the print.

External Perimeter
: Set only if there aren’t a lot of overhangs.

Extra Perimeters

This setting helps with reducing the chances of the infill showing through the perimeter outline. It checks against any slopes and curves and adds additional perimeters there to improve overall look.

Avoid Crossing Perimeters

Use this setting if you are noticing artifacts from oozing or retraction. It is suppose to cause the nozzle to travel along the perimeter minimizing oozing and retraction artifacts.

Ironing

Adds small amounts of filament to fill holes and gaps. The nozzle is supposed to overlap the previous passes several times to iron it out. The number should be smaller then the nozzle size to keep from making uneven lines.

entry.title: Email Subject Lines
entry.content:
During my time at McCoy, I was involved in a significant rebranding project that required extensive communication, decision-making, and dissemination of detailed information. To manage this effectively, I employed a Responsibility Assignment Matrix (RACI) to organize groups and individuals according to their roles and responsibilities.

A common challenge with email communications is ensuring high open and follow-up rates. Fortunately, my interest in social media led me to discover an insightful LifeHacker post about writing highly efficient emails used by the military. You can read it here. Intrigued, I decided to implement its suggestions, and I still use them today.

Email Subject Lines

Start with keywords (ALL CAPS REQUIRED) that relate to the recipient’s role and the project’s nature. These become familiar over time but can be adjusted for specific occasions. Follow these keywords with the email’s purpose, all in the subject line.

  • ACTION - Compulsory for the recipient to take some action.
  • SIGN - Requires a signature from the recipient.
  • INFO - For informational purposes only; no response or action required.
  • DECISION - Requires a decision from those responsible.
  • REQUEST - Seeking permission or approval from the recipient.
  • COORDINATE - The recipients need to coordinate efforts.
  • DELEGATE or CHAMPION - Opens the decision up to the recipient to delegate to their team.

This approach allows recipients to immediately understand the email’s nature and urgency.

Email Body

In the email body, clearly state the Responsible, Accountable, and sometimes Consulted groups or individuals so they understand their roles and expectations. I use abbreviations in subsequent emails but ensure the initial email clearly defines these roles to maintain clarity and accountability.

Keep the content concise and focused, providing detailed information without distractions. The goal is to present all necessary information within a single screen to avoid long-winded messages.

By following these guidelines, you can create efficient and effective email communications that drive action and clarity.

entry.title: HTML5 Input Patterns
entry.content:
The patterns presented here are a compilation gathered from blog posts and websites, offering solutions and troubleshooting for regular expressions (RegEx) in various input fields.

Regarding email addresses, it's advisable to rely on browser capabilities for validation, as discerning their complexity is best suited for developers, allowing browsers to integrate it into their validation and security libraries.

Basic Password

This pattern looks for the basics in password character combinations.

Pattern: ^(?=.*\d)(?=.*[a-z])(?=.*[A-Z])(?!.*\s).*$

Uppercase, Lowercase, and Numbers

Not so basic password

This pattern incorporates special characters, and a minimum of 10 characters.

Pattern: (?=^.{10,}$)((?=.*\d)|(?=.*\W+))(?![.\n])(?=.*[A-Z])(?=.*[a-z]).*$

Uppercase, Lowercase, Number/Special Characters and a Minimum of 10 Characters

Alpha Numeric

Upper or lower case letters and numbers that's it.

Pattern: [a-zA-Z0-9]+

Uppercase, Lowercase, and Numbers

Username

A pattern to ensure a username is within 2 - 20 characters long with upper/lower case alpha numeric characters, hyphen, underscore or period in it.

Pattern: ^[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9-_\.]{1,20}$

2 - 20 Characters including hyphen, underscore and period

US Postal Zipcode

Pattern to quickly check against the US Postal System pattern.

Pattern: (\d{5}([\-]\d{4})?)

##### or #####-####

Canadian Postal Code

Pattern to quickly check against the Canadian Postal System pattern.

Pattern: [A-Za-z][0-9][A-Za-z] [0-9][A-Za-z][0-9]

A#A #A#

Numeric Postal Code

This is a fairly generic pattern for several countries out there that don't have anything overly complicated with their postal system.

Pattern: [0-9]{4}

####

Basic Date

Checks to ensure its year, month, date with the corresponding possible values.

Pattern: [0-9]{4}-(0[1-9]|1[012])-(0[1-9]|1[0-9]|2[0-9]|3[01])

YYYY-MM-DD

Full Date Validation

This date pattern incorporates year restriction, and checks against leap year.

Pattern: (?:18|19|20)(?:(?:[13579][26]|[02468][048])-(?:(?:0[1-9]|1[0-2])-(?:0[1-9]|1[0-9]|2[0-9])|(?:(?!02)(?:0[1-9]|1[0-2])-(?:30))|(?:(?:0[13578]|1[02])-31))|(?:[0-9]{2}-(?:0[1-9]|1[0-2])-(?:0[1-9]|1[0-9]|2[0-8])|(?:(?!02)(?:0[1-9]|1[0-2])-(?:29|30))|(?:(?:0[13578]|1[02])-31)))

YYYY-MM-DD

Time

Pattern to ensure valid time is recorded.

Pattern: (0[0-9]|1[0-9]|2[0-3])(:[0-5][0-9]){2}

hh:mm:ss

Price

Pattern to ensure a proper price is entered with dollars and cents to the nearest two decimal places.

Pattern: \d+(\.\d{2})?

#.##

North American Phone Number

Phone Number pattern for Canada and the US.

Pattern: \d{3}[\-]\d{3}[\-]\d{4}

###-###-####
